title: How to get interested in reading books - Quora

response.answer_text: The best way to get interested in books is to read books that are interesting, and to associate books with something positive, like relaxation or comfort. I learned to love books because my grandmother read to me every night before bed. She found books that I liked--a series of mystery novels about a girl named Mandie Shaw--and read them to me a chapter at a time. She encouraged me to read passages for myself and eventually just handed me the book and reminded me to turn out the light and go to sleep at the end of the chapter like usual. She praised me for my love of books, indulged me in my desire for more books (it was the one thing I could almost guarantee she would buy me if I asked for it), gave me complete freedom with choosing what I wanted to read, and very rarely told me I couldn't read anything unless she felt the subject matter was truly inappropriate for my age. Because of her, I associate books with safety, with happiness and home, with family and also with personal identity. And I think the key is that books were never presented to me as a goal or a chore or a requirement, but as a treat. They were a short delay to bedtime, a reward for being good that day (two chapters instead of one!), a gift and a sign of affirmation. They were also a source of freedom and choice that was relatively rare in our household, because she was pretty strict about things like movies, television, toys, clothes, and time spent on the phone or computer. I read very little that would be considered classic literature, mind. I read a lot of The Babysitter's Club, Sweet Valley High, Nancy Drew, the Star Wars Expanded Universe, fairy tales, fantasy, science fiction, and horror. I did grow to love Agatha Christie and Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. I also eventually developed some favorites that fall in or near the literary canon, though not many. Christie and Doyle aside, I'm not a fan of Brit Lit, and I especially can't stand Jane Austen. I've soldiered through a few books simply because "smart" people are supposed to read them apparently, but for the most part if it doesn't grab me within the first two or three chapters, it goes back to the library and I move on to something that doesn't put me to sleep. And for all that most lit professors would (and have, and do) call my approach to reading sophomoric and pedestrian, I developed a sense of grammar, spelling, syntax, and vocabulary anyway, not to mention excellent reading comprehension. As it turns out, you can learn "how to words" just as well from things that are interesting as you can from, say, War and Peace.* That being said, how you foster an interest depends on a few factors. Do you seek to interest yourself in reading? Your students? Siblings, friends, your child? Every person is different, and not everyone will come to love reading books the same way. Some people will simply never come to love reading books at all. I personally find this unfortunate because I do love them so much, but I also acknowledge that books are not the only way to tell stories and foster critical thinking and communication skills, nor are they inherently superior to any other method of doing so. (There's this literary conceit that books are better than movies, television, video games, images, and the internet. And it's just that: a conceit. It has everything to do with a sense of superiority that educated people often have and feel they have earned because they are educated, and nothing to do with any inherent ability of one particular format of one particular medium to convey meaning more effectively than any other.) So why do you want to create an interest in reading books? Who are you creating this interest in? What do you want to accomplish by doing so? Are there factors that may make this difficult to do? That last one is important. For instance, my mother has ADHD, and because she was growing up and being educated primarily in the 1980's, this went completely undiagnosed and untreated until adulthood. She never enjoyed reading as a child because she didn't have teachers who understood her inability to focus, and so she associates reading with a chore and with being constantly scolded. Some people read for enjoyment or relaxation, but people with ADD, ADHD, dyslexia, or other learning obstacles may have a harder time enjoying reading books than others, not because they're stupid or uninterested in reading, but because reading is often more difficult and frustrating for them. With the right tools, these obstacles can be overcome, but they have to be acknowledged before that can happen. I think it's great that you want to foster an interest in reading books, whether for yourself or someone else. Happy reading! And if you give it a try and it doesn't work, I hope you find a medium that does, whatever it may be. When you do, I hope you enjoy getting stories and ideas from it, and never let anyone make you feel bad just because it doesn't happen to be a book. *No offense whatsoever to anyone who is actually interested in War and Peace. It is simply not among the things that I personally find interesting.

Pat yourself on the back for asking this question. I have often met people who complain about how reading is just boring and they just can't seem to take time out for it. Well, if you ask me, my End Semester Exams are approaching and I am in an endless battle of procrastination and more procrastination. Yesterday, I was supposed to finish 2 Units but what did I do? I finished a 400 page novel. Don't ask me how. Anyway, you see, reading is so captivating that it makes you want to forget your crucial tasks and devote time to it. This isn't necessarily good. However, I will tell you one thing, I wasn't a reader myself and to be honest, as lame as it sounds, I started reading Enid Blyton & Roald Dahl. This sparked my affection towards paperbacks & hardbacks. There was something so enthralling about living in another individual’s world and live in their adventure. You also learn so many things! For example, vocabulary and the subtle art of exaggeration. So, if you want to get interested in reading, read a relatively small and easy book about your interest. For instance, I would highly recommend books like Night by Elie Wiesel or Man’s Search For Meaning by Dr Viktor Frankl if you like Wars. They are compact & not difficult to read. If you like Mysteries, Agatha Christie is a wonderful writer to start with. I have read countless books by her. I am not telling you to start with a book like War and Peace or The Fountainhead. Take your time with it. No rushing. Be patient with it. You can't expect a suitcase full of thrill and an enthralling plot from the first chapter itself. A plot takes time to build. If you don't enjoy the book, keep it aside and read something else. Life is too short for reading books you don't enjoy. Also, one more thing that works for me. When you buy books, you are essentially spending a lot of money since books aren't cheap. So, you have 4 options:- Leave it in some forgotten nook and corner of your house and let it get dusty and mouldy.Gift it to somebody because you want nothing to do with it.Or, which works for me, feel guilty of spending your hard earned (in my case, hard given) money. Let the guilt do it’s effects and voila! You might just actually read a book.Again, skipping the book and watching the movie instead.For choosing the right book which is very vital, Ask people for suggestions. Ask your 6th grade English Teacher perhaps.Search online. I usually check goodreads!Remember that no book is too “below par in terms of intellect” for you. An innocuous looking Children’s book with illustrations might just teach you a lesson for a lifetime. It might throw you back into your childhood. It’s about perspective.Finally, if you got past Buying a book & not discarding it, here is the fun part. This is what I do when I want to enjoy reading:- Switch off your internet. This is the biggest distraction.Listen to music if you want to but not something filled with ‘Dhuchuchuk Dhuchuchuk’ & ‘Yo Yo’ & other inappropriate things which I wouldn't like mentioning. You can listen to peaceful music. There is this app which plays really luxuriate sounds like that on the ocean or falling raindrops. That helps me.Tell everybody to not disrupt you.Also, remember one thing, if you have thoughts regarding abandoning the book and watching the movie instead well, think of it like this, when you watch a movie, you are watching it from somebody else’s perspective. But, when you read a book, you are understanding it from your own perspective. For instance, I had a completely different image of Dumbledore. It wasn't Michael Gambon.Give the book a chance to blossom. Trust me, they aren't boring.After you read a book, discuss it with somebody. I don't know, maybe write a review.And if you got through all these 3 steps, reward yourself by buying another book and perpetuating the cycle. Good Luck!

When first starting out you want to make reading a habit. If you are already bored of books but you want to get started then I suggest at least getting a good 20 minutes in. Read books you are interested in. Think about what concepts, settings, and genres interest you. For example, if you like space, mathematics, mechanics, or anything in the field of science, science fiction might appeal to you. If you like wizards, magic, knights, and strange monsters, fantasy might appeal to you When reading, get rid of distractions, and use it to reduce distractions. When you are reading, you dont want to have distractions or you will not understand what you are reading. One of the most important things in reading is comprehending what you are reading. Eventually, when you have a great interest in books and are reading ones you enjoy, your time spent on superficial things like social media will tank. When I needed to get a lot of books read last year, I would read every time social media came to mind. Set a goal. A lot of avid book readers set goals for the amount of books they read each year. Setting a goal makes you become more motivated to read more books. At first you may want to set small goals, but as you read more and more you should set the bar higher and higher. The most important one out of those four is reading books you are interested in. if you read books you dont enjoy, you will not want to read books. Dont force yourself to read a book you dont enjoy. Just because everyone else has read it and enjoyed it, doesn’t mean you should have to read it just to feel included. Suggestions: I am a Fantasy, Sci-fi, and Historical Fiction (I’ve also been considering picking up books on philosophy like “The Book of Five Rings” or “The Temple of The Golden Pavilion”). Suggestions for Fantasy: Lord of The Rings trilogy, and The Name of The Wind Suggestions for Sci-fi: Dark Matter, Snow Crash, Remembrance of Earth’s Past (Three Body Problem trilogy). I dont suggest starting with Dune or Cryptonomicon. Both are very complicated, but very VERY good. Suggestions for Historical Fiction: The Walking Drum, Lonesome Gods, Last of The Breed (all three are by Louis L’Amour, a historical fiction author that mainly writes Western fiction) Sorry this was so long. I just really like books :)

Make reading your only option. When I was 12 years old, my dad took my family to his ancestral home in Kerala,India.  Now I grew up in Dubai, a city where everyone had TVs filled with cartoons, and I played endless online computer games, in the young era of the internet. So visiting this house, where my father grew up and played in, was a shocking experience for me. The village is a beautiful place, and the people are genuinely kind and friendly. The tea is superb, and the cool breeze induces the most peaceful sleep ever. But there was one major drawback. There were no cartoons to watch or computer games to play. For the first time, I could not think of anything to do to amuse myself. Time had never been so slow in my life. I remember walking up to my dad, whining for the spoilt child I was, that his ancestral house was boring and that I didn’t have anything to do. He must have felt very happy to be back at his real home with his mother. He was busy running around meeting the villagers, and going to the food markets. So he didn’t waste time on my negative energy. He simply said “Well, find something to do” and walked away. After finishing my tea at breakfast, I was so bored that I went snooping around in the old cupboard and shelves in the dining room. A book fell on to my hand. It was a dusty old book. which had been untouched for about twenty years. I was surprised to see the name of my uncle on the front page, and struggled to imagine a younger version of my usually easy-going uncle, studiously reading books in college. In this village, where technology had yet to catch up, where I was bored out of my mind, I was introduced to Stephen Hawking’s “Brief History of Time”. I didn’t need motivation when reading was the only option I had. I opened the book, and was hooked. I can’t pinpoint why the book grabbed my attention. Maybe I had always been fascinated by space, and this book was trying to explain its mysteries. I remember getting up in the morning, trying to get done with breakfast as soon as i could, and opening this complex book, trying slowly to understand what Stephen Hawking wanted to tell me. I was only 10 years old, so it took me a while to get through this book. I spent the next two months at the ancestral house, reading this book when I felt bored. The day I finished the book, I was lying on my bed. It was about 7am,and the sun peeked in through the windows. I turned over the last page, and just turned my head towards the light. And I knew I would never be the same again. My perspective has shifted. I was wondering about entropy all the time. I was mesmerized by the Big Bang, the expanding universe, and mysterious dark matter. It was beautiful that I could know so much about things I probably would not interact with in my lifetime. And I could converse with an amazing human being. In one book. That is an out-of-body experience, literally. When I left to Dubai, I took this book with me, and it continues to be one of my favorite reads of all time. I would have not found this book if I wasn’t crying from boredom. I would have been blissfully unaware, receiving instant gratification from cartoons or computer games.Try to get rid of social media, Youtube, and Candy Crush for a month. You might be surprised about where your boredom takes you. You want motivation? You won’t need it. Make reading your only option.

The Will to read is half the battle. So congratulations - you’re halfway there! Because you clearly know you want to start a reading habit or else you wouldn’t have asked this question :) I’ll lay this out in 3 personal commandments to abide by and 5 shorts steps to start the habit. And i believe you should be a reader in no time. 3 Commandants: Not an interesting topic, no chill: Do not for the love of humanity read a book on a topic that simply does not interest you, but others say is cool30-Page Rule: It is not a crime to put down a book if after 30 pages it still hasn’t sucked you in. Throw it away. Unfinished-book guilt is real. And the sooner you accept it and come to terms with it the better. Move to the next one on your list2-way conversation: Make reading an active activity, and not a passive one. By that I mean when you’re reading, really read. Take notes in the margins and scribble your thoughts on the pages. Make it a conversation between you and the author. Make out with the writer’s brain by puking out your own brain onto the pages. Fiction, non-fiction, biography, doesn’t matter. Reading actively and writing your thoughts, emotions, responses will change the way you take in the content. Go wild. No one else gets to see what you wrote :)okay, now The 5 Steps: Ask 5 friends or family for one book that blew their mind - and if the topic interests you or the author seems cool, buy the book. A physical paper copy. You’ve officially just started your library. And trust me, years down the line this will be the best part of the inheritance your children will receive (my collection has 300 right now and i love it :)Block 30-minutes every night on your calendar. Put away the laptop and phone. They belong in the living room at night, or at least need to be off. Have a cool shower right before you get in bed, put off all the lights, except one behind your bed, and get cosyAim to read as slowly as you want. No pressure. Wanna read a sentence again? Do it. Wanna read it 5 times? Do it. Go at your own pace. There’s no rush. Just try and finish 15 pages before you fall sleepKeep the book right by your bed. And bookmarked - self explanatory. You’ve gotta make it as easy as possible to actually pick up the book and read, or else our reptile brains make stupid excuses not to do soWhen you finish, tell someone the story in your own words. Tell your mom, or your partner, or write it out on Goodreads, or your blog, or wherever, just tell someone how awesome or horrible it was. In your own words.3 Commandments + 5 Steps + Time Voila!

The fact that you are interested in reading books is amazing. I believe books are underrated and can have a profound effect on our lives. To get interested in reading books, start by thinking in specifics, what are your exact challenges : Do you buy books and surround yourself with them?If no, this is your first action step. Buy physical books, Buy ebooks , buy a Kindle. Borrow books from friends and family. Join a public library near you.If yes, great, you have passed the first test in your pursuit of reading.You have books(bought/borrowed) but somehow never end up reading them.If yes, make sure to keep your books at strategic places where you can’t miss them. Place them at your bedside table, coffee table, the backpack you carry on your office commute or while traveling etc. If you read ebooks, keep a few books downloaded on your device always so you can start reading it whenever you find the time.If no, great, move on to step 3.You start reading books you bought and just can’t make yourself to read any more after a few pages because it doesn’t interest you enough or you can’t find the time.This is where finding the right book is extremely important. This is where getting book recommendations tailored to your needs might help.If you tie your reading with a purpose, you will be more incentivized to read. You can read books to solve a problem, to learn something you don’t know or even just for pleasure. I read books to gain perspective about all sorts of problems, for example: I am working on building a book recommendation product known as BookPrescriber. As with most early stage ideas, the challenge is finding the audience. To solve this problem , I read a book ‘Traction’ by Justin Mares, Gabriel Weinberg and it gave me several eye-opening ideas as to how to go about it.I would suggest you to think of a problem you are facing, it can be a personal or a professional issue: relationships, work, stress, depression etc. Choose anything that bothers you and then read about that, I am sure you’ll gain some perspective. If there is a very specific problem you face, and you need books tailored especially for you, try personalized book recommendations.Read Non-Fiction to be more knowledgeable everyday. Read biographies, auto-biographies or memoirs to learn about the lives of others. You’ll be surprised how many people face the same issues as you, you’ll find solace in the fact that you aren’t alone in your struggles. And you can even learn the strategies applied by other people when faced with similar issues. Read about health and wellness, travel the world, get introduced to philosophy or just read to broaden your mind.Read Fiction to be entertained. Read Adventure and mystery novels for some thrill, short stories when you are starting off to read, books that will take you around the world in the comforts of your home.Read Graphic Novels - They are just like comics, and if you love reading them, and feel guilty or worried that this isn’t counted as reading, change your world-view. Things are changing, comics and graphic novels are finally getting their due. This year, Sabrina by Nick Drnaso was the first Graphic Novel to be nominated for the long list of the Man Booker Prize.I believe there is immense power in books, find the right book for your life and read more everyday with purpose to become a better version of yourself.

Wow! That’s possibly one of the best questions I would love to answer. Let me tell you a story. There was a kid having a very high mental acumen and decent memorizing skills. Since his school-days as he was able to grasp everything pretty easily he did not care of reading stuff much from his textbooks and found reading to be a pretty boring stuff. Whenever he started reading his textbook he would quickly grasp the gist just from what his teacher had taught him and skip reading the remaining part as he thought it to be a waste of time. The time went pass by in a flash and he ended up in a decent engineering college where he encountered people having a very good appetite for reading, where most of the people had reading to be on their list of hobbies. Puzzled and confused he approached a friend of his and asked him what makes him devour books? His friend just passed on a smile and took him to the library. Their the friend paused near the fiction section and passed on a book “The Da Vinci Code” by Dan Brown to him and asked him to just read the first lesson of it. Puzzled by the terse reply from his friend, he just heeded his friends advice and went back home and started reading the novel. Ironically, he ended up reading the first 10 chapters and ended up reading the whole night. So, what made the guy who haven’t read a great deal about anything his whole life end up reading, which definitely was not his genre? It was the plot of the story and the way the author kept the reader involved in his story. The author’s way of writing, the words used, the detail of each and every subject of the story got the better of the reader. Since then he repeatedly kept asking his friends to suggest him books to read. In a similar way, to gain an interest in reading books, start with some genre which you like, be it romance, autobiography of your favorite sportsmen, mystery, inspirational books, anything which you like. It will help you gain an appetite in reading. A good vocabulary is not a prerequisite to start reading books, it is something which can be developed over time. Once you get an edge over reading, shift to different genres and try reading as many different types of books as you can. After reading, say a chapter of a book or a whole book for that matter, sit down and write a summary of what you read or some quotes which happened to impress you the most. If not write then at-least spare some time with your siblings or your parents briefing them on what you read cause they are the people who will definitely spare some time for you no matter what. This will help you improve your retention capacity. *A lot many people abandon reading just because they are not able to connect the dots after a while, this is where writing the summary or narrating it before someone comes into picture.* The guy now had developed a voracious appetite for reading and ends up reading at-least one book a month by simply adhering to the tips mentioned above. But that’s not just the end of the story, the reading hobby got the better of that boy and he ended up writing stuff as well and you just happened to read one of those.

I have a friend who is a software engineer that never got a degree because he has a learning disability.  Now, that might not be your situation at all, but as a preliminary matter, it might be worth getting yourself tested--it's possible you have dyslexia or another type of issue that could make it difficult for you to read or retain prose, despite the fact that you can read code.  That aside, I have two suggestions for developing an interest in reading.  The first is that you have to find something to read that you find interesting.  You say that you've bought a couple of 300-400 page non-fiction books, but I get the feeling that you're not particularly interested in them.  If you can't spend more than 10 minutes on a newspaper article, 300-400 pages of nonfiction may not be your style. Instead, I suggest you start with shorter works, such as long-from journalism, or short stories.  Longform is a well-established website that collects longer articles about specific topics.  There are also countless well-respected short story writers, from Isaac Asimov and Ray Bradbury (sci-fi) to Alice Munro (Noble-prize winning author)--you just have to find someone that you find engaging.  If you're really more interested in non-fiction, you might try something generally agreed to be highly readable and approachable, such as Bill Bryson (a very engaging historian) or Malcolm Gladwell (social science).  Surely you have a hobby of some sort--try reading something to do with that.  The goal is to try reading a variety of things that sound interesting to you to find something that engages your mind and helps you retain the text. My second recommendation is that you actively approach your reading with a particular strategy to retain the information you're going to read.  This is going to take some experimentation as well, but you might keep a highlighter or a pencil in hand so that you can make notes, underline, or do whatever else you need to do to get your mind thinking about what you're reading.  In a similar vein, there are a whole bunch of websites that claim to have strategies for helping people to retain what they've read, through outlining and the like.  I haven't used any of them, so I can't tell you what will work.  But it may be that one of them will come through for you.   It may very well be that you're never going to be able to just reflexively retain things you read--some people just can't do that.  But you may be able to learn ways of helping yourself do it.

First find the time. It is no good thinking you are going to read the books you have chosen, if you have not made the time to read them. It is a like buying a computer. If you do not make room in your life for one, you will almost always find that you will not enjoy the 'thing' in your life. You are supposed to enjoy this life. With books, first understand that they are a product that many people have invested their time an effort in producing. If you look at books purely as books, and do not look at this wider picture, you will not get the most out of the experience.  The first rule is that once you have prepared your life for books, only buy a book you cannot walk away from. It is like buying a pet dog; it tells you what pup to take away from the pet shop. You should never buy a book for any other reason; borrow one, if a friend has recommended one to you. That is what libraries are for, and friends with books. The second rule is, when you have the book in your possession at home, take time to scan the workmanship of the publisher, author, read all the stuff other people don't read, like footnotes, acknowledgements, and certainly the preface or introduction. Remember that somebody spent a lot of time writing this book, and put in more man hours/years than most people spent at their paid work. In most cases it is a work of love. Only then settle down to reading the book. I tend to leave the book around for days, even weeks, and some books lie around for years until I am ready to read the book that chose me. Books are dialogue. The author is in some kind of dialogue. If the book chose you, then you will find that the author is in dialogue with you. If somebody recommended it, then it is very likely the author is in dialogue with them, not you. That is why the two other rules are important. You should put in the same amount of love and full attention what you read the author puts into writing it. If you do, both parties are enjoying intercourse from a distance. It is not unlike making music, only both parties are not present in the same room. Enjoy!

This year ( by 18th July 2020) I have read over 14 books of which 5 were read in just the last 17 days. I mostly read self-help and psychology-related books. Most fiction and biographies can be so interesting that you may wanna read instead of watching Netflix. Whereas some self-help books can be so boring that reading them can be a torturing experience. My Good Reads Collection: Ashutosh Agrawal’s 'read' books on Goodreads (24 books) Here are my tips and tricks for you to start reading books. Everyone is so hyped up about books and their benefits. So I too thought about reading books but it turned out to be a dizzying experience. Guess why? Because at this time, due to youtube, Instagram, and Tiktok, our attention span has reduced drastically. Most of us can’t focus and read lines of text anymore. It’s natural. But we still have got other options too. One such option is instead of reading books, listen to them. Yeah, I am talking about Amazon Audible. But wait, Ash! Audible is too expensive. Yeah, it is. But if you can spend money on Netflix or Amazon Prime i.e. Entertainment you should also spend some on Edutainment. For those of you who can’t afford Audible or any paid service, I have a secret recipe for you. Step 1: Download Ebooks (.epub) from online websites or convert PDFs to Ebooks using online tools. Step 2: If on a PC download Freda, it's a fantastic ebook reader. Android also has some free options like Moon Reader [Bonus: Use OpenDyslexic Font] Step 3: Start Text To Speech and enjoy listening to that robotic voice reciting the book to you. Now, Now, don’t go away, it isn’t as bad. I am using it for the past 1.5 years and it’s nice. Set it to your desired pitch and rate and it will be perfect and natural. Just try it once and if it doesn’t work for you then what other option do you have? But let’s not stop here. Let’s talk about a reward system which will motivate us to read more and more books. I am an anime fan, so it’s really hard for me to choose between anime and books. So I have told my self that time spent in reading books = time spent in watching anime Typically reading a page may take from 1–2 min, which means reading a 200-page book will grant you over 3 hours of anime credits as a reward. Now I had a little debate if 2 page of book = 1 min of anime ( If edutainment > entertainment ) OR 1 page of book = 2 min of anime ( If edutainment < entertainment )  So set your daily goals in exchange for something you enjoy a ton and isn’t harmful. Like read 30 pages a day to watch anime for 1 hour or Read 1 book to watch a movie All the best for your journey of reading books and don’t forget that finishing a book (goal) doesn’t give as much joy as enjoying the book (journey)

Reading requires long span of attention. If one is unable to read for a long time it means he or she is surrounded by distractions like social media’s TVs, radio, unnecessarily gossiping. One need to be careful what is creating diversion in reading and remove those environment stimulus.Start with small easy to grasp books. Books market are flooded with these kinds of books who prey on fast finishing habit of readers. Chetan Bhagat, Stephen King, John Grisham are few example.Even after above step one is not able to concentrate on reading. He or She should go for children authors. Ruskin Bond, Enid Blyton, Roald Dhal. If one is again finding these books difficult to concentrate then go for comics or children short stories. Start from bottom don’t loose hope. U will reach.Try to imagine what u read. This will help u develop “taste” for reading. Whenever u feel u can stop reading and ponder on interesting points. This way u can enlarge ur attention span and cognitive thought process.Once u pick up reading habit. Do two things :Upgrade ur reading level & Join the discussions about book. U can go for goodread app, or Facebook groups to discuss ur reading. This will gradually prod u to read more. U will also inspire to try new genre.Don’t shy discuss ur new read in appropriate environments. This will help u to generate interesting and satisfying mental exercise. U will be know man for books discussion in party and social gathering. U will find new readers, new suggestions, new challenges all will cumulative enriched ur reading habitsHappy reading.

For me, reading used to be a very demanding task as compared to e.g watching videos due to one factor: I didn’t have any expectations to remember the latter. I felt as if in order to progress in the book, I had to remember and analyze carefully what I had read. In the end, I feared that all the reading would accumulate in only weakly latent memories. Plus, watching the videos felt more stimulating and were only confined to short durations. This pessimistic mindset about books changed whenever I realized that: Books as a form of entertainment are superior to the short and not consistent - yet entertaining - videos. Their nature of being consumed during a long time gives them a great depth of knowledge which might say something about the world. This, in comparison to the videos that at max gave me shallow facts.Reading the right fiction book, can be an adventure. By supposing a thematic concept and a thematic statement after a while to prove using the book, reading the book becomes more than merely reading. The way to accomplish the task is to interpret the book’s content and search for quotes, in the same way an adventurer grasps its surroundings and collect keys for the dungeon. Since the reading is personal, the thematic statements and concepts won’t necessarily be put to the test, so there is no pressure like the one school can evoke. When the concept has been thought through so much, it is sure to be retained.Taking notes is good. While this might feel much like school, it is a good way to relieve the burden of having to remember too many things and thus the paranoia of forgetting 99% of the book and complicating the analytical process. I take a my notes on a comfortably big paper accordingly to below:Front page: dedicated for notes, chapter summaries and answers for deeper questions about the bookBoth notes and chapter summarizes are noted using few words that go to the core of what is meant to be notedChapter summary: e.g a chapter about a king whose ungodly ways of life supposedly provoked God’s wrath by flooding whose kingdom later fell in civil war can be summarized as “hedonistic king =>flood&war”. With those key words I should be able to recall most of the chapter. Every chapter summary has the number of the summarized chapter to its left.Notes: e.g an interesting fact. Every note’s left has a dot as a separator.Deeper questions: questions that might be answered throughout the book and aren’t easily answered and might say something deeper about the book.When finishing a page, skim through the page and summarize each section with few words, then re-read the last section. This way you will better remember what you have read.Example: Back side:From the top to about 2/4 to about 3/4 of the page, depending on book and paper size, is dedicated to important characters of the story. Each name is underlined and has space from the next character in which you write down key words about their character, such as traits or visuals.The rest of the page is dedicated to the thematic concept and statement. Since the thematic concept only requires one word and the thematic statement only one sentence, it is possible to put the two on the same row, albeit giving the latter potential space to the next row.If the thematic statement is expected to go to another row, the “quotes (affirming above)” will be put where it’s expected to end, otherwise the title will be simply put on a new row. This is where you put interesting quotes you find throughout the book accordingly to a format defined below. Once you have decided what thematic statement the book has, you will look through the quotes and underline the ones that affirm. The simplest formatting of a quote will look like: P<page number><first word of quote>,<last word of quote>. On one page there could however be several interesting quotes and one word might appear several times. That is why the following format might be needed: P<page number>(<first word of quote <second word of quote>), <last word of quote>. If a quote stretches several pages, simply make the it P<start page number>-<end page number>. Full formatting: P<start page number>-<end page number>(<first word of quote> <second word of quote),(<second last word of quote> <last word of quote>). To save precious space, the starting Ps will also be the ones separating the quotes.When reading a non-fiction book, the top becomes reserved for questions about the book to make my reading more active, enumerated like: “1 How is X in book similar to Y? 2 How is X implemented? 3 What happens when X is implemented?”. The numbers will serve as reference points for notes on the front page giving information in regards to questions and points these questions in the thematic concept/statement and quotes section. The front page will become notes and quote-area using the format named aboveexample of backside for a fiction book The real reason videos took so much attention was due to them being conveniently accessible on the same device I am being productive on most of the time. When you are on your computer and switch to a video for 10 minutes, it takes some time but you are still on the same device and can therefore quickly go back. Changing to a book on the other hand, is effectively declaring to yourself that you change activity. Reading does therefore have to take place before or after reading hours. I think that there might equally have to be an need to rid oneself of high stimulants that are social media in general in order to like the slow pace of books. However once it has been achieved, much more simpler things can be appreciated in life. By equipping oneself with something to note on, reading becomes a memorable adventure.

First of you should consider why you want to read books. Is it because you see others reading? Because you want to read? Because you want to be more intellectual? You want to learn something? Be entertained? Other?.. There are a thousand reasons for reading and if you know yours thats a good place to start. (perhaps just wanting to read a book is a good one. .. Then having a set time and read the book in intervals (perhaps chapter by chapter or for 10–20 min each and every day) Also consider just what it is about books you might be apprehensive about. If its the length then comics and even children’s books might be a good place to start (try the thicker ones though as the thinnest ‘easy to read’ might be a bit too simple though. With comics there are a great variation and many are even made for adults/teenagers.. Never mind the Japanese manga (well worth a try - even more so if you like anime (its usually fairly similar or even exactly the same (.. except the anime has fillers which the manga does not have) If its the actual books (that you may or may not get the point of reading for entertainment) then factual or even historical books (non-fiction essentially) might be a good place to start. If you choose a topic you want to learn more about (and are interested in) then that might make it easier to read. When it comes to fiction you should try the various genres (and even various writing styles) and try to figure out which draws you in the most. I personally find a lot of science fiction boring but I do love a good fantasy novel (on the telly I don’t/rarely watch fantasy movies and often science fiction so..). If you like watching the television there are shows and movies that originated from books. .. and its also a good place to start (there’s a reason they were filmed in the first place). Essentially - consider why you need to motivate yourself to read books (I’m not you after all) and go from there :) You can do it. It may require forcing yourself to read at first and to try out various types of books to find what is the easiest for you to read (and perhaps even consider reading well recommended books) and other than that I wish you good luck. Have fun reading :)

Actually you have asked two questions... One is How did I get interested in reading books? You want to know my experience. Then in the description you have asked how can you get the same effect that you get from movies while reading a book...  I will try to answer both... First for the question 1: How did I get interested in reading books? I got interested into reading books at around my grade 6/7. During those times mostly I like to read the classics and short stories. As things don't hold my attention for too long. I was mildly into comics but not too much. Things changed when I saw the first movie of the Harry Potter series. I loved the movie and wanted to know what will happen next. I later came to know that the movie is based on a book series. Hence I pleaded with my mom and bought the second book in the series. It look me a whole 10 days to read through the book. I was struggling as it was the first novel reading experience. But I was not prepared for the experience, while I am reading the book a movie was being played out in my mind. I am creating a rich and pleasant experience that I have never experienced.  And there it all started for me.. Naturally I got hold of the other harry potter books released at that time.. From there I went on to read the Lord of the rings series... And  for me things really spiraled out from there... For your second question: How you can get the same experience from reading a book? Reading a book is an effort and for each effort you need a reward. So what kind of reward your are expecting depends on validating the worthiness of the reading effort. Imagine you want to escape the tiredness of a stressful day, a fantasy book might offer you an escape to a magical place. You are looking at having the edge in your job, a book on the recent trends or new technology might give you the edge you require. Hence you need to find the good balance of effort and reward system to help you pick up the habit. As with all new habits, it grows on you over a period of time. After a few days, reading might no longer be an effort but will become a reward by itself.  Giving you the double whammy you needed !!! Some points to note: Reading fiction is a very pleasurable experience if you have a reach creative mind and are able to imagine the things you read. If you want to cultivate the reading habit start with something simple, read a book based on your current movie or TV series, it will make the mental creative process easier. Then you can move on to other genre of books.  Reading non fiction, for me,still is an effort in spite of years of reading experience. But I am after the rewards it provides. And finally thanks for this question, it has really reminded me why I was in love with my books in the first place... Have to get back to my magical places !!

The most important thing you can ever do to increase your interest in reading is to NOT read books that don’t interest. It sounds really simple and obvious, but a common mistake people make is that they force themselves to read and finish a book they genuinely don’t enjoy which just makes them not to read any other books. Some kids grow up not liking to read, because they have to read certain books for school that they don’t enjoy and end up assuming that all books are just as terrible to read. Another simple action to do is to read the summary of any book before you read. Goodreads is an amazing website that not only will give you a full summary of the book, but also let you see how many stars they book got and others comments on the book. Doing this will let you choose books that actually sound interesting to you before you read them, so there is less likely of a chance you end up not liking the book. Really once you start reading, you start to follow certain series, authors, or genres and then your interest will just keep going on it’s own. But to start interest, the best way to research books YOU like/want to read and to not read books you hate just because you want to read.

How can I get interested in reading books?  It’s simple. Read books that you are interested in. And as no one on Quora knows what kind of things you like to read, you need to think about that yourself. I could recommend books that I love to read and they may be the most boring books ever to you. It would be a waste of my time and yours. Think about what you like to read. Do you like to read stories? If so, then there are so many genres to choose from in the world of fiction. Could be crimelove storiesscience-fictionliterarythrillerfantasymagic realismOnly you know what kind of stories get you excited. Once you know that, then those are the kind of novels and stories you should read. But maybe you have no interest in fiction, maybe you like non-fiction. That could be historybiographyself-helpphilosophyand many othersAgain, determine what kind of books you are interested in, then start reading those.  A good website to find books is Goodreads. This is like Facebook for people who like to read. You might find a book you are interested in and you read it. Then you want to find more books like this. Go on Goodreads and put the book title in the search bar. It would then show you the book plus other books that readers also liked. It literally feeds you a choice of similar books to read. Goodreads also has groups. Maybe you are really into crime fiction. So you join a crime fiction group. Now you can ask the members for book suggestions and they can offer you some choices. Very soon, you could build up a list of books that you want to read. And all in a genre or style that you are interested in. But asking other people what books to read on Quora is not useful. They could give their suggestions, but these are books they like. And you may not like them at all.

It’s possible that you’re trying to read the wrong books, or at least the books that are wrong for you. Reading isn’t spinach; it should be enjoyable, not forced, something fun, not something you do because it’s good for you. Give some thought to what you like in your non-book life. Science? Adventure movies? World-building video games? There are almost certainly things that interest you. Make a visit to your local independent bookstore. This is important, because they are more likely to have knowledgable staff who can talk about books. Tell them that you’re not a reader, but like horses or food or politics, and ask for suggestions. Leave the store with a couple or three books, and one of them may “take.” Once you find one book you’ve enjoyed, you can go back to the store and tell them that you hated Hemingway and loved Faulkner or loved A.O. Wilson’s writing about ants, but would like similar writing about mammals, and they’ll be able to help you find more books you’ll enjoy. Fast forward a decade and you’ll be making a second trip to IKEA for another Billy bookshelf. Good luck, and have fun!

Light up your IMAGINATION!Summary: start small. Do you remember how you learnt how to write?  You probably started off by attempting to represent the world around you on some kind of medium. This could have been your mom’s wall(she almost killed me), sand, or paper based materials. From this point you learnt the alphabet, individual words, and then slowly worked your way up to sentence construction. Unless Andrew is a Martian child prodigy, he’s going to need time to become comfortable with writing.  Since we are talking about reading, I would advise you to start with comics. I know you that you are probably rolling your eyes right now, but they will definitely make reading fun, and they will lay a good foundation for taking on Schopenhauer and Nietzsche in the future ;-). When your attention span has sharpened/ when regular comics start to feel too short for you, move on to graphic novels, and then get your first book. If comic books and graphic novels are not your cup of tea, start collecting and reading magazines that have content you are interested in. Read them until reading becomes part of your lifestyle. The only reason I am not suggesting that you start off with a book is because I want to ease your mind into the whole skill of reading. Once your mind is able to associate reading with being an enjoyable act, it will be much easier to make it a lifelong habit. 2. Be CONSISTENT. Once you start reading, do not stop. The best way to not stop, is to ensure that you are reading books that you like. Being picky about the content you feed your mind on the initial stages of your reading journey will reduce the likelihood of you burning out and quitting. 3. Read The process of reading becomes a self-sustaining reaction after some time. You’ll know that you’re on the right path when you can’t imagine your life without books.

You don't force yourself to read books. You develop a habit of reading books, by first finding books than interest you. Here's my suggestion: Go to your city public library or local bookstore, and do a gallery walk through the gondola aisles. Just pick up any book title that interests or intrigues you or just strikes your fancy.  In the bookstore, just take a shopping basket from the store along with you. You may even want to talk with other book lovers in the store just to get a rough sense of their favourite books. As soon as you feel that you have enough of your selections, go and sit at one quiet corner to browse the titles: front cover, back cover, inside flaps, preface or foreword, tapestry of contents, and even the index, bibliography and index at the back of the book. Take your time. Feel free to flip the pages so as to skim and scan some passages [based on your earlier exploratory search] that catch your immediate attention. Narrow down you final selection.  Buy them, and go home to read. My rationale behind this exercise: you should read what interests you or catches your attention! Reading is the best personal investment you can make in your life-long and life-wide self-education.

Thanks for A2A. Starting out on any journey is the most difficult part. So start by reading some good quality Literary Fictional novels that have been written in modern English, easy to understand and maintains a fast pace. Then try and follow these recommendations: Try reading a few pages every single day.Try reading novels of different genres. You will figure out what you love reading, and what does not suit your palate.Try getting a specific time of day wherein you could read quietly. A rush-hour traffic in a London tube could work for some; for me it does not. I need a quiet place to read fast.Try not getting bogged down into details till you become a mature reader.And most importantly— do it for the right reasons. If you do not love it yourself; it is a pointless act. I know too many individuals who made New Year resolutions of becoming a terrific reader of books by end of the year to impress a girl or boy; gave up by mid-January.To begin with; you ought to read novels that are easy to read, comprehend and analyze. Gradually move from Stage 1 to Stage 2 and eventually perusing more complex longer pieces of Literature. Stage 3 are complex works of writing; and Stage 4 is the pinnacle of world Literature; requiring a focused and polished mind to analyze and comprehend the world of Classical Literature. Hi, A good book can be highly satisfying, it can teach us various things beyond our daily horizons. If reading is a habit you’d like to get into, there are no of ways to cultivate it. Firstly remember reading a book is highly enjoyable, if you have a good book. If you have a lousy book and you are forcing yourself through it so consider changing the book, because reading should be enjoyable and not a duty. Other than that, try these habits to cultivate reading habits Set times: You should have a set times for reading everyday. At starting level you can start with reading 10–15 minutes everyday. This is the time you have to read no matter what.Always carry a book: Wherever you go take your book with you. Like wherever i go, the book stays with me. if there is a free time or i have to wait for someone i spend my time reading a book.Make a list: Keep a list of all the great books you want to read. You can keep this in your notes or pocket diary. Keep a running list and keep crossing out the ones you have read. By this method there will always be a curiosity in yourself to complete your list as early as possible.Find a quiet place: Find a place where you can sit quietly and concentrate on your book.Keep a log: Similar to reading list, keep a log with not just only name of the book but also the start date and finish date of your book. Even better keep a note of your views about the book. It is extremely satisfying to go back to the log after a couple of months to see what all books you have read this entire period.Follow all these steps and start seeing the change in you towards your love for books. Good Luck with reading books. Thanks

I’ll just list them down below: When you get so lost reading them that you even spend time with them for hours and you would hardly realize thatBe it fiction or non-fiction, you always (and I mean always) have something to learn from them.Books are something which can leave you heartbroken, but that is never a reason to hate them, at all.Books are great stress busters. Trust me on it.If it is a fiction one, you sort of make a connection with every fictional character you read about. And there comes a point in your life when the key things you learned in a fictional book/the character’s life, actually help you in tackling some issues in your life. Now that I was typing this, I realized it could be applied for non-fiction books as well.There might be more things which can be the reason we find books appealing, but these are the ones I could think of.

I read a lot of my books in my high school. As I grew up, I gave up that habit making excuses such as not having enough time, too much coursework or saying that I am exhausted and want a break. I realised I now saw reading as another task instead of an activity that I enjoyed. My recommendations: Identify what interests in your life? Romance? Fashion? Sports? Adventure? Fantasy? More professional ventures like Marketing, Consulting, Technology? Believe me, anything that you like would have a book on it. That is how you start or get back to it.Do not go after the famous books that everyone is reading. Go online and read descriptions of books in the field that you are interested in. From there on, go with your gut. It is like being in a restaurant. You choose to eat what you want and not what others are eating. Of course, take their opinions on recommended dish but don’t just go along with it if it doesn’t speak to you.Give the book a read for 10–15 mins before sleeping each day. It could be a part of your sleeping routine or maybe travel routine (read on a subway, metro, in the car). Make a conscious effort to spend some time with it everyday.Switch books if you don’t like the one you are reading. Just do not give up. Most people give up after they have one bad experience but that is never good way to go. Like with anything, you have to be consistent with it.Tip 1: Don’t pressurise yourself into getting into reading immediately. It will not happen. Take your time with a book but to keep yourself accountable, have a deadline.Tip 2: Have a reading buddy to discuss the contents maybe? Or join a book club.Hope this was helpful. Have a good reading experience!

I have told this so many times to almost all my students: Have a habit of reading - Anything and everything.“If you spend one hour a day to learn about a topic,a year later, the knowledge you gain will be more than 99.999% of the world’s people.” Are you that person? Who is interested in knowing more and more. The one who keeps oneself busy. I believe Curiosity is the value you need to embrace to motivate yourself. That’s the hidden key. Start it slow. Take your time. You’re not in a competition to read 10 books a month. How can call the things that you have learnt as knowledge when you don’t remember to use when you need the most. So, Start reading newspaper, magazines, columns, sports, digest, comics, illustrated cartoons etc. Find your interest. It takes time and proceed further to books. Read books that has less no of pages to start with. Read 4 pages everyday. Even the world is gonna die, make sure you die after reading those 4 pages. When you find yourself in that process perhaps in other 2 or 3 weeks. You don’t need quora or google or someone like me telling you what to do. The books you’re reading would have done the damage. You know what to do? That’s the power of reading. It makes you wise. Happy Reading! P.S The answer applies to all the other questions you have asked me. So, I am not answering the rest of the questions. Feel free to ask anytime or visit my other answers to get a collection of books to start reading. All the Best.

Hello Remon If you surround yourself with people who love to read, your conversations with those like minded buddies, shall be a catalyst into more creativity within that subject area. Join a book club! To motivate yourself to go to one, in case that is an stumbling block, write down the benefits of reading. When I watched Les Brown’s videos on Youtube I was reminded of the need to read a minimum of 15 pages a day. Les Brown reads 2 to 3 books a week. He is friends with Brian Tracy so most likely he has mastered Speed Reading, Accelerated Learning Techniques and maybe other advanced methods of retaining information. I currently keep a revision card at the back of my current book for which I input new words I seek to memorise, then look up plenty of examples of their usage in sentences and paragraphs, and then begin to utilise those, in order to increase vocabulary and hence ‘Linguistic Intelligence’ (ref: Howard Gardner). If all else temporarily fails, read this as you will be on the floor in fits (I have this):  Regards Bhavin

Read Fiction Books Or at least, read really good fiction books.  Whenever I have a period of time where I’m not reading, I find that it only takes one really good fiction book to get me hooked again. Why fiction? Well, I find that fiction books have a way of getting me drawn to the plot to the point where I am obsessed with finding out where the story goes. Nonfiction books (except for maybe biographies and memoirs) just don’t have that addictive plot that makes people remember why they love reading so much. This same concept can be applied to you. If you haven’t read in a while, find a really good book and just start reading it. Chances are you will get hooked onto the book and then kickstart your reading habit back up again. Here are some of my book recommendations that will (hopefully) get you hooked onto reading again: To Kill a MockingbirdThe Book Thief (my FAVORITE book of all time, I highly recommend it)1984WonderThe GiverThese are just a few suggestions, but you should go out and find a book that you know will get you hooked. Now get reading!

Like gardening, growing as a reader can be a challenging and rewarding experience. 1. Put on your Gardening GlovesShow yourself how exciting reading can be. Be a reader by setting a time each night that you turn off the television and computer and pick up a good book. Talk about your books regularly with family book sharing; a time when children and adults can share their exciting new books. 2. Dig up an InterestFind fiction and non fiction books that revolve around a special interest or activity you enjoys. Finding a fiction series that piques your interest or imagination is a great way to keep urself excited about reading. 3. Find the Right SeedsTake trips to the book store or local library and explore. Librarians are great resources, ask for their book recommendations! Ask them for recommendations about what reading level or type of book you can handle independently. You want leisure reading to be pleasurable; not a task you will struggle with. 4. Nurture the Reading SproutRemember that reading is important at any age. This can be a special bonding time before bed time that you can enjoy reading  5. Watch your Seedling GrowSet reading goals for your household. Track how many books you read as a family or how many minutes a day you read. Set up a chart and watch your reading motivation grow and grow!6. Admire Your Bouquet take a minute and celebrate the joy of a good book and the pleasure of growing yourself a reader. Reading is a joy, an escape, an adventure; revel in the beauty of your bouquet! Remember seeds take time and nurturing to grow into beautiful flowers. You are the roots of your budding reader, make books and reading an exciting part of your household and you will be amazed as you watch your reader grow! Thank You

Reading books can prove to be a very beneficial hobby. You can make use of some of these ways to get interested in reading books: Don’t force yourself to stay glued to your book for a good half an hour. Start by reading for 10 minutes 3 to 4 times each day. You can read while having a meal alone, before going to bed, while having tea or coffee, etc.Try reading at a quiet place away from all distractions. No television, no mobile phone, no noisy family members, etc. should come in the way of you and your book reading.Start by reading fun and easy stuff like short stories or fiction books. Don’t jump to heavy reading right away.Don’t just stay glued to one genre. Try out multiple genres and note down the ones that interest you more than others.If you want to get books of all genres completely free of cost, you can order them from a site called MyPustak. They only charge you the shipping fee and deliver the books within 4 to 7 days.

To make reading a habit you need to make sure that you keep your efforts consistent. Starting and then stopping mid-way will be of no help to you. I would suggest you to start small. You can take up reading the newspaper daily. And I mean a physical newspaper, not a e-paper, reading online will only lead to distractions. Being consistent is important, keep on reading daily to make it a habit. Meanwhile, take up a book, preferably something which is easy to understand and short (like Animal Farm by George Orwell) or even something like a comic book (if you find it really difficult to read books). Make it a task to read at least 20–25 pages everyday. As you keep on reading, you will develop a taste for, and soon number of pages wouldn't matter to you. Again, being consistent is the key. Don't limit yourself to one genre, or one type of reading material. You are trying to develop a reading habit to be more well read and informed about the world and various aspects, aren't you? That's why, diversifying your reading material is important. Sooner or later, you will get a taste for reading yourself. Choose what you read wisely, and you would be up and reading regularly in no time. Hope that helps. Thank you for reading.

You can get interested in anything, if you know exactly what you are looking for. It feels very good to know that you want to get interested in reading books. Reading books is something which can create wonders for you and can transform you totally.  First of all, you need to know what genre/category you prefer or more precisely what kind of books you want to read and if you have no clue about which genre to go for, than start with some self help book. If you start reading a genre that you don’t like, you might start hating books because you will get bored by reading it and this experience will make it difficult for you to ever get back to books again. After you have chosen your genre/category,try to start reading books written by authors of your country and try to choose some recent books. It will get you started and will be very beneficial for you in the beginning , because if you start reading foreign author’s books, it can be difficult sometimes to cope with the language style that has been used and the way it has been presented. Some Indian authors that I can suggest you are Durjoy Datta, Chetan Bhagat, Ravindra Singh, Amish Tripathy, Robin Sharma, Arundhati Roy, etc. I sill remember the first book that I chose to read, “THE NOTEBOOK” by Nicholas Spark. After reading mere ten pages I felt literally terrible, I wasn’t able to understand what’s really happening in the story, the style of writing was so hard for me understand. So it is a good thing that you start out by reading some short books that take less time and where the required English proficiency is low as compared to other. Reading is an easy task but to fully grasp the meaning of the literature and get the most out of it, is something which needs practice and time. It may not work in the case of fictional novels but if you are reading non-fiction books, you need to have good reading habits, good vocabulary, English practice and some previous experience of reading books. As you develop your interest with time, then move on the reading books which are master pieces of literature, books that challenges your thinking. Try to change genres of books that you read after sometime, it will improve your insights, equip you with some new thinking and provide you better perspective of the world. Keep Reading and Keep Learning. Here is my link for “What’s the best way to read a book”: Sandeep Mehta's answer to How do I read a book? Also, the books that I’ve been through Sandeep Mehta's answer to What are the best books you've ever read? Why?

Sometimes being in an environment that you feel you want to be, automatically opens the first door of self realisation towards your ambition…Being surrounded with books helps the genesis of psychological magnetisation towards books… To be able to create an interest you have to have a feeling of 100% dedication towards that interest.. I would suggest, visit book exhibitions, join a book club, have some discussions, and of course not forgetting the library.. And always begin with something that has an instant appeal for you… it could me an instruction manual for your car/ or it could be DIY/ short stories/ or simply about a hobby that you would like to develop further… It could be a book on gardening/ or even a holiday manual that elucidates exciting travels and adventures…or even news paper Give yourself just 15 minutes ( or more) to read anything, but have a self discipline to do it religiously every day.. Go through some inspiring life quotes to make you feel ambitious and positive, this in turn should influence your thoughts to do something meaningful and something that will entertain your mind to become enthusiastic about trying something new… or, develop further an already existing hobby….
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Suliman Ali and Mary Purity

response.answer_text: As human beings, we are a selfish species. We act on our own best interests. Whether we know it or not, there is a reason why we do things we do. So if you want to develop an interest in reading books and make it a part of your life, you need to know your ‘why’. Stealing an example from a book I am currently reading: If you were asked to jump in a river full of crocodiles at a moment’s notice, would you? Obviously not! Now imagine that's the only way you can save your best friend/loved one from drowning, or rather being eaten. Would you jump now? What changed? Your ‘why’! So to develop a true interest in reading, you might want to take some time to think, what's the reason behind this urge? Do you want to expand your knowledge of a particular topic? Are you just a life long learner and a curious person? Do you want to detach from reality for a little while and take a break? Do you enjoy being in a fictional world every once in a while? What is in it for you? Once you know your ‘why’, your interest, motivation and everything else will follow.

To get interested in reading a book, first of all, you need to determine what kinds of books you want to read. If you want to find out a solution for your life’s situation, a How-to book may interest you. If you have passion with Math, a Math book may take your attention. If you want to understand about the thrive of human kind, a historical book can help you, etc… Second, you need to start slowly. If it is the first time you read a book, you just need to set for 10min a day to read it. After that, you can gradually increase your time of reading. Finding a relaxing time, a comfortable sit, and open your book. Third, you need to know what kind of information in that books interest you. You may start at that chapter first, and others later. And last, there’re a some questions to help you read a book easier: What question(s) would you ask the author if you had the chance?Where else could you learn more about the topic of your reading?What’s the goal of the author? What do you think his or her motives are for writing?What are the least – and most – important parts of what you’re reading? What are the main ideas?Who is the main character? Who are the supporting characters?What are the motives of the character? Are they described in the reading or just inferred?If you could rewrite this reading, what would your version be like?What does this reading remind you of? Any particular feeling, thought, or event?Are there other readings that offer a different perspective or opinion?What part of the reading did you not like? What was your favorite part?

Start with short books in a genre you like. If you like mystery, stick with authors like Robert B Parker’s Spencer series or the Travis Mcgee books by mystery great John D. MacDonald. If you like paranormal/fantasy try the Rosie O’Grady’s Bar and Grill ebooks by B.R. Kingsolver or the Innkeeper series by Ilona Andrews. Action thriller/spy novels? The John Resnick series by J.B. Turner or Wayne Stinnett’s Jesse McDernnitt series or Ian Flemming’s James Bond books. Fun caper books? Books by Ross Thomas - all stand-alone books like The Money Harvest, The Briarpatch, The Seersucker Whipsaw or try Hugh Laurie’s The Gun Seller. Action romance? Agnes and the Hitman by Jennifer Crusie and Bob Mayer or Jana DeLeon’s Miss Fortune series. None of these books would be accounted difficult reads, but they are entertaining and well written. Reading is a wonderful indulgence and a very enriching experience. The first step of getting interested in reading is to appreciate the fact that there are books on almost every topic and subject under the sun. You need to identify what interests you the most and start with books on that topic. Walk into a bookstore, read the back covers of books, take your time in scanning a couple of pages, check online for ratings and reviews, and buy a couple of them. For starters, pick up an easy to read and thin book (not more than 250 pages). Set a daily target of reading 10–12 pages and you’ll be done with the book in around 20 days. That’d be a good beginning. Make an account on Goodreads. Rate the book and write a short review of how you felt about it. Read other reviews to understand the different perspectives that people present. Make it an immersive experience. Then pick up another book and repeat the process. Gradually, transition into other genres. Start maintaining a library. They look wonderful on the shelf. As you start enjoying the pursuit, you’ll start wanting to expand your collection. It requires a little effort in the beginning but post that, it becomes addictive. Happy Reading!

Let’s take a look at range (not a complete list) of possible emotions interest being one; each being a dialogue that goes something this:Excitement- I don’t know what’s going to happen….but whatever it is I believe it will be very positive (great possibility). Interest- i don’t know what’s going to happen….but whatever it is I believe it will be positive. (Some possibility) Fear- I don’t know what is going to happen but I assert that whatever it is it will be negative (bad). Apathy- I don’t know what’s going to happen but whatever it is I don’t care. Catatonia- I don’t know what’s going to happen, don’t care and don’t care that I don’t care. From the above text you should discern that the key to creating “interest” is finding possibility; finding something of value that the text might offer you the reader. You might ask someone who has read the text, read the jacket text, intro, or chapter titles to get a sense of what possibility the text might offer . You might ask yourself what you think the text might offer and then read to discover if your speculation is correct (or not)? And if not what then is the possibility offered? You might ask yourself what your mood is in regards to your speculations regarding the text and ask yourself where that mood came from? Is it connected to the text or some other aspect of life? If some other aspect, what action can you take to resolve that? Why this mood if connect to the text? Is it realistic or a prejudice of some kind? Mare you awake and rested? Or tired and worn out? Maybe you need a nap! A good chair? A good light? New reading glasses? A reading buddy who is reading the same book? Good Luck!

Find a time to read where there is a limit to how long you can read. This will encourage you to start because you know that you won’t be forcing yourself for too long. And chances are, by the time you have to stop, you will want to read on and will be looking forward to your next reading session. An example of a situation where you can read but there’s a time limit is during a commute to work in the morning and again in the evening. I studied English Lit in University and was forced to read about 6 book per class/ 5 classes a semester. This went on for 4 years! So I went from someone who loves leisure reading to someone who associated reading with not sleeping, being forced to analyze something that I understood from the first time I read it, and exams. So as you can imagine, it took me a couple of years to get back into reading for the pleasure of it. And when I finally decided I was going to start again, I found that I still couldn’t just sit on my bed and read. So the next day, I took the book with me to work and read on the 35 minute train ride to work. And of course, two pages in I was like: Oh My God!!! How haven’t I done this in so long?!? So far it’s been a year and a half of me regularly reading again but I still pretty much only read while I’m on public transportation commutes. I still find it hard to read when I’m free at home because I’d usually rather shut off my million and one thoughts and reminders with some mind numbing Netflix show… But I’m a fast reader so I still finish about 2 novels a month just reading during my commutes and I continue to be a huge fan of reading!

At lunch break If you’re part of the 9 to 5 club and never know what to do between 12 and 1pm other than talking about uninteresting things with your colleagues, bring a book. At night The most common approach. Reading before going to bed might be harder as your mind will be tired after a long day. Elaborating on the point made by Surabhi Naik, I would give the example of Game of Thrones TV series. In this day and age, many people do not read for pleasure. There are many reasons for this. Some may believe that reading takes too much time or effort. Others may never have enjoyed reading at school and can't imagine doing it for fun. Some may simply never have encountered an environment that fostered a love of reading. However, reading can greatly enhance your life experience, and there are ways to make it even more enjoyable, whether you do it frequently or just for school or work assignments. As George R.R. Martin, author of the Game of Thrones books, once wrote, “A reader lives a thousand lives before he dies...The man who never reads lives only one.” 1. Why learn English through literature? If you want to become more fluent in English, you need to keep pushing yourself. Reading original English books is a great way to do this! Even if you are an intermediate English speaker, you can still use simple novels and books to make good progress. Let’s take a look at how reading can help you improve:  2. How to improve your English by reading simple books There are many different ways that you can use reading books in English to improve your language skills. However, it is important to find the books and methods that work best for you. Remember to choose novels that suit your level of English and personal interests. Reading should be interesting and fun. If you find it boring or difficult, then change the book! These 8 tips will help you get started: 3. Genres of English books Before you choose a book to read, it is a good idea to think about your favourite styles or genres. Whether you like science fiction or romance novels, there are thousands of English books out there for you. The table below gives some examples of books from different genres: 4. Start with Books which are easy to Comprehend.  Our Brain is a muscle. If it has not been regularly reading in past few months that means it was not getting used. Then if you suddenly start with a book which is difficult to comprehend then your brain gets tired quickly. Therefore it tries to find out many excuses for not reading that book. This is the reason why people start reading a book but do not read more than one chapter. Therefore, initially start with a book which is easy to understand. To summarize, first decide in which area of life you want to grow. Select the books of that category. Do the overview of the few books. Then start with “easy to comprehend” books. After reading few books in this manner, you will overcome the initial inertia. Then start reading any book which you wish. Start with a very short, very fast paced, doesn't require too much investment novel. I started with Enid Blyton, but if you are past a certain age I won't recommend that, so you should probably start with Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone. Now as you find it difficult to pay attention to it for long spans of time, in the beginning you'll have to just go with it. You'll feel like getting up after some time, so get up. But don't give up on the book. Come back after some time and continue. If you've chosen a good enough book, eventually you'll get engrossed enough to see it through to the end. If it is the first in a series, and I think you should pick the first of a series, you'll have gotten a fulfilling experience but you still will want to know more and will read the rest of the series. And as later books in the Harry Potter series are longer, you'll get used to reading longer books too. By the time you've finished the whole series, you'll be a novel reader. Also, Harry Potter rules.
