I teach reading to students and teachers, and I have a son who was dyslexic when he was in school and had difficulty reading. The strongest point I make to teachers, parents and students is to find a book that INTERESTS YOU. Don’t worry if someone else doesn’t like it. All that matters is that YOU like it. Find something that allows you to escape the normal routine and takes you into a different world. My son, who had difficulty reading, hated to read until he discovered Stephen King. I personally do not like horror, but he loved it and it got him reading. Since I write on topics having to do with music, musical instruments and performance, and - this question was routed to me, personally - I take the context here as “How do I teach myself to read (music)?” Is that correct? If so, obtain basic texts or Internet sources on sight reading music. Learn the basics of counting measures, time signature, note values, etc. Then find sheet music, standard notation for tunes you know by ear. These tunes might be “Mary Had a Little Lamb,” or “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star,” and practice counting the note values for each measure. But start with sheet music in front of you for tunes that you already know by ear. Then match your “ear” training with your “sight training,” and counting measures and finding scale notes will become easy.

You need to find a topic you’re interested in: fiction or nonfiction, fantasy or historical fiction, autobiographies or science books. Then look up books in that genre. Or you can take a gamble and go and peruse that section. I’d visit the library to find a wide selection of free books (with membership). This may take a few tries, as authors have different writing styles. Next you have to sit down and read. This is the difficult part. I recommend starting with a daily goal; try ten pages per day, or reading for ten minutes, whatever works for you. This may feel like a chore at first, but when you find the right book you won’t be able to put it down. I’ve stayed up many, many nights stuck in another world, unable to sleep until I found out what happened next. Good luck!

You can start with a small book like “Who Moved My Cheese?” so that it’s not overwhelming and you are not tempted to close the book and never open it again. Also, choose the category which you like the most. And then read a variety of books. Take small steps in developing this habit so that it will be with you forever. In your first attempt itself if you start with a 500 pages novel, it can become boring and you will never try again. Also, there can be a lot of distractions you might have when you start reading…either you check you phone, or browse something on the internet. Here’s what I would suggest….invest half an hour per day from your schedule, go to a library, keep your phone on silent and read without any disturbances. Do this every day and you will develop a habit of reading. Once you are at this stage, then you won’t need any kind of motivation to have a book in your hand :) Hope this helps !!

I know the feeling. My boyfriend is a filmmaker who eats, sleeps, and breaths film, but can become restless when reading. By contrast, I read books and have a hard time watching movies. His mind is most definitely engaged when he is watching a movie in a way I am not, so I disagree: watching movies is not mindless, especially if it's difficult subject matter. Books are exactly the same way, where light material is effortless and difficult material challenges you. The same for every type of media. Becoming a good reader is all about building habits. Don't feel discouraged if you want to put a book down after only a few minutes. Pick it up the next day and the next. Your brain will soon be wired. I'd recommend starting off with something that's truly effortless: a YA book or something you've already read. Then work your way to finding that one that stays with you.

Only read stuff you really enjoy reading.Keep a book you enjoy around you and try to read just a page or two when you feel like procrastinating. At the moment, whenever I feel like playing computer games or fooling around on the internet, I decide to just open my book first. Sometimes this means reading a page or two, but usually, I get caught up in it end up reading 20-30 pages before I get around to whatever procrastination I first intended. Of course, this only works with books that you don't have to struggle to read.Stop reading a book if you lose interest in it - especially at first, when you don'y know yet which genres interest you.

I do not profess to be a voracious reader but hopefully the following points would help: 1. Try to pick a topic of interest (for example World War I; then google books on the subject)  2. Instead of reading generally, try reading books that carry a certain argumentation.  In the above example, a war account of a participant may pique your interest. 3. Try to read articles, preferably long form.  It is essentially reversing the process that used to happen in the pre-social media era. We would read books and then read articles and with time and social media, our attention span has become infinitely shorter. Try to reverse the process. It's a difficult thing to so but the efforts are extremely rewarding.

For someone who prefers moving pictures to words on a page, I would say start with graphic novels. Graphic novels have a little bit of both; kind of like picture books for young adults and kids at heart.  Graphic novels have a variety of storyline a, including renditions of popular movies. Rick Riordan's Percy Jackson series has a bunch of graphic novels. A good graphic novel series I would recommend is the Elf Quest series. I'll also say that graphic novels are slightly different from comic books in such they provide more narrative than comic books, which is why, for those loving movies who want to get interested in books, I suggested them over comic books. Hope this helps!

I have a friend who boasts about the number of books he reads in a month. He likes to recommend selections of his favorite genre: fantasy. Honestly, I could care less about the number of books you read or whatever material it covers. If something does not interest me, then why should I waste my time with it? If you seek the motivation to read something you don't like, then here is my suggestion for you: read the summaries of each chapter beforehand; you will gain a better understanding without the burden of confusion. Reading the summary before and after also helps to consolidate your memory of what happens. If you want to read more as a pastime, then find a topic that you like. Do not force yourself to like something that has no bearing. If you do not know what you like, then try to explore. Learn something new and read more about it.

Are you asking how to motivate yourself to read a book you don’t want to read? I’ll suggest a few ways. Largely related to community, a primary interest of mine. See if you can find intelligent, emotional opinions on the book by people who excite you. I love to use critics who draw me in to motivate me to better use my precious artistic time and money. In addition, while friends and loved ones may not be as knowledgable like people who devote their lives to good reading, we benefit a lot from sharing with them. It does a social bond a lot of good to have shared experiences. I suppose you could even call it shared effort, and as they say, a burden shared is a burden lessened. Or… lessoned. The compare/contrast/discussion/debate/argument stuff that comes after can be a real pleasure to look forward to, too. If you truly like learning and growing. Often the stuff we aren’t interested in is actually done well, and that sometimes means… its an area we have tons to learn about. The stuff we’re easily drawn to? It can keep us in our bubble, or our echo chamber. Growth keeps us humble too. Reminds us we’re less powerful than we think. And always remember that power corrupts! :)

Start by finding an author you like…but might be a surprise to find out who that is and they might not write in the genre you expected. Ian Fleming’s James Bond books are very well written (& will surely appeal to most boys). Mark Twain’s Tom Sawyer is action, action, action. Louisa May Alcott’s Little Women will probably appeal to a lot of girls (& with luck, Jane Austen when the girl becomes a woman). I enjoyed Agatha Christie as a teen (but stick to Miss Marples and Poirot: avoid Tuppence and Tommy like the plague). Be wary of those touted as the “best ever”…they tend to be promoted by people who don’t like novels at all, and are supposed to gbe good because they’re more like “history”. Russian appears to translate badly into English (from my experience).

I love questions. In fact I often like questions better than answers. So, rather than simply answering this question. Let me ask some questions. Is it the act of reading itself that you don't have passion for? Have you tried listening to audio books? I have found that listening to an audio book while doing repetitive, boring, or tasks that don't require much thought is a great way to get through books that I would never in a million years have time to actually "read".Do you have trouble reading? So people just haven't found their niche, and when they do, they become voracious readers. But, many people don't like to read because they have difficulty reading. They have a learning disability that makes reading slow and they can't retain what they read. There are ways to compensate though, and professionals who can help improve reading skills.

Try reading the description of books that you are likely not to hate, then see if they're available as audiobooks. A good narrator makes the story alive - assuming you prefer fiction. But audiobooks are a good alternative for non-fiction as well. Try going over the table of contents first. Some books don't need to be read in a specific sequence, and you can skip the chapters that seem less appealing. As you discover what topics or genre pique your interest, you will begin to devour books. And remember: one of the greatest gifts for readers is that they are rarely afraid of loneliness, as there’s always a good book nearby. Best of luck!

You really don't like to do something when someone forces you to do it. Do you? Then why force yourself to read books if you don't like it? In my honest opinion, you cannot develop an interest in reading if you are inherently not interested in it. Reading is something natural and it comes to people naturally. Patience and persistence. While I started reading my first ever book, I understood nothing. English is not my first language. I started with the great “Hardy Boys”. I understood a word or two on a whole page which gave me a hint of what is happening in the story. I was frustrated. But I don’t want to give up. I continued. These are some of the things I check out I suppose: How attractive is the title. Has the author put in any thought into the marketing of the book I mean.The book cover. Again, this too shows how much the author wants you to read their book.A synopsis, either on the back cover of the book or on Google.Recommendations by people whose taste I know and agree withDoes it belong to a series or author whom I'm already following?Most importantly the Preface. This is one of the most important things because this is where there is a conversation between the author and reader about the book itself. If this doesn't impress me, I'll drop the book.Some other impermanent factors like book size, available time, cost of the book etc.I don't need all of these to be ticked to read a book. Not always should you make rational decisions, once in a while, you can pick up a totally new book and blindly dive in. Who knows, you may even like it.

Thinking is Hard. Reading a book mindfully is hard work. We pay by our precious cognitive attention, which is the key currency of our brain. Many times, the reading process is frustrating. Reading is one of life’s great pleasures. The first thing you want to ask yourself is what interests you and what relaxes you. If you are interested in history or business or science or whatever, that gives you a place to start. There are several ways to find good books in your areas of interest. Go to Amazon and poke around in your area. Look for books with a lot of positive reviews .2. Go to your local library and ask the librarian for recommendations in your interest area. 3. Go to a good local bookstore and ask them for recommendations. Then — and this is very important— give yourself permission to sit down and devote some tump to reading. If you have picked a book in your area of interest , then be sure to also pick a book that will relax you. It might be be anything, but don’t overlook fiction. A good fiction book will transport you out of your life and into someone else’s. It can make you laugh, make you cry or simply fascinate you. Good luck! You are about to take your life and mind to a brand new level.

I start with a cover. If you want to read a book that is as easy to absorb as watching a movie, I'm sorry to say that it won't happen. Short of reading picture books, reading is a mental activity that requires a certain level of literacy to enjoy (e.g. if a person isn't fluent in reading English it becomes a struggle and less enjoyable activity). I'd suggest trying out the Harry Potter series. It got millions of kids reading big paperback books before the movies ever came out. If you've seen the films and enjoyed the story and characters, you will be more inclined to enjoy the activity of reading and hopefully develop it as a habit!

Books are wonderful, amazing things that are filled with a wealth of information that can be used to benefit yourself and, more importantly, the rest of the world. Unfortunately for the rest of the world, you chose to read Quora instead. *out of character note* Books are pretty cool. I recommend getting a kindle for ~$80 because it makes it so much easier to carry around books. Also look into Overdrive because it lets you rent books from your library. Once I got my kindle I went from reading around a book a month to reading around eight books in a month.

If you have a tough time just reading for reading’s sake, think of a subject you’d like to learn more about. Like cannibalism. Are you new to the subject and looking for an introduction? Then maybe Bill Schutts Cannibalism: A Perfectly Natural History is for you. Are you a seasoned cannibal and looking for something more scholarly? In that case, Avramescu’s An Intellectual History of Cannibalism might satisfy your hunger for a good book. Or, if you’d like to read fiction, try reading something that seems challenging to you, and yet still sounds interesting. This summer I hope to read The Tale of Genji which is a classic of Japanese literature, considered to be world’s first modern novel. It’s a very thick book that weighs about 5lbs written in a tiny font. To me, it’s an intimidating book, but it shouldn’t take me more than a couple of weeks if I just devote a spare hour or so whenever I get a chance. Usually when I take on a big book, I can’t wait to get back into it—as opposed to smaller books that can be read relatively quickly.

Books, unlike movies, requires us to invest rather than spend time. The best way to cultivate this habit is to start with small books - those that can be finished in a single sitting; any 50-60 page book will do. Then choose the genre you are interested - horror, adventure etc. in Fiction, or any non-Fiction. Now comes the difficult part - one where we have to sit through sometimes frustrating hours, where the inner voice constantly questions this activity of ours. Once you can go beyond this, book reading, for that matter any activity, can become a habit!

First of all, know what your genre is. You can determine it by the kind of movies you watch or the kind of stuff you like to do. Once decided, look for books relating to that genre. Look for novellas because early readers can't tolerate a story worth 500 pages. Don't stick to just novels. Go for magazines, comics, periodicals, newspapers. Just read. Contemplate on books. Think of them as life. And once you fall in love with them, there is no going back. Happy reading. :)

Go to the public library and get yourself a card. Then browse the aisles, and pick out 4–5 books that just look interesting to you. Go to your bedroom half an hour earlier than you usually do. I would start by downloading ebooks. Find a genre that speaks to you, not what other people think you should read or what’s on the best seller. Find a genre or trope that you enjoy and work from there. Choosing a book that you have no interest in won’t help at all. You have to read what you are interested in. Nobody reads because they enjoy translating symbols into meaning in their head. People read because they like fantasy stories. They like information about welding. They like perspectives on eighteenth century politics. And the same person who likes reading about one may not necessarily like reading about another, even if they really enjoy reading about what they like. Choose whatever it is you are interested in, and view the reading as a tool, a conduit, to connect you with the story or the information you desire. It’s all about what you enjoy.

Find a subject you’re really interested in or very curious about. Something will catch your eye and you’ll be very much caught up in that subject & book. Are you interested in non-fiction, true success stories? Rags-to-riches stories? What about self-improvement type stories? What if you found a new hobby in the course of your search? Have you ever read the life story of John Goddard who, on one hot summer day when he was bored decided to write a list of the things he’d like to accomplish/do/enjoy during his lifetime? Here is a brief youtube clip that will show you what happened as a result of him writing his life list.

Pick it up and start reading. If it hasn’t grabbed you and dragged you in within a few pages, give it up and try another. When you find a book that interests you, keep going until you want to take a break, mark your spot, and resume reading later. The motivation to continue should come from within, triggered by the interest you’ve already discovered. Read until you lose interest or finish. You may have noticed there are millions of different books extant - if you look, you are sure to eventually find some you like.

What are your interests? Try and find a book that aligns with things that you enjoy. The best way to motivate yourself is to make sure that reading is a rewarding experience for you. It may be hard to begin, but if you commit to dedicating 10–15 minutes each day to reading an interesting book, you may find that immersing yourself in a different world becomes appealing. The only thing is, you have to REALLY commit. No skipping a day or two because you're too busy, or too tired. Maybe you could start with a short book; when you finish it, you'll have a feeling of accomplishment (again with the rewarding feelings), and hopefully be more motivated to finish another one. On the other hand, maybe you'd prefer to start a series. In my personal experience, when I read the first book, it's very hard to stop without getting to the end of the series. You'll find that you planned to read one book, but ended up reading seven (*cough* Harry Potter *cough*). Hope this helps :)

My first question to you. 'Do you read newspaper' ? Do you read the editorials and articals in magazines ? Thats the way to start. Virtually on every possible topic you can think of. Again and importantly, do not let anything distract you.

What are your specific interests? Read books about and around the subjects that interest you. If you like wildlife you could read books on wildlife by conservationists and then go on to read biographies of conservationists or novels set in a wildlife setting. The same thing applies to any other area of interest. Once you get into the habit of reading you will soon find that you find it difficult not to read something and then you will start to read what is to hand and in that way broaden your interests.

Try to find books that connect to your interest. Do you have any hobbies? Are you interested in certain films - usually made from a book? I love researching about neuroscience so it is easy to delve and get lost in those books. I also love a romance novel - the classic and well-written ones. Also do you like a comedian or actor who has started to write such as Dawn French or David Walliams The key is finding something that already interests you.

Read something you're crazy about it. It could be the biography of your favourite sportsman or your dream place. It's only the initial 10 minutes which makes all the difference, make sure to force yourself to read atleast the first few pages. If you're really passionate about the subject it's very difficult to stop. Good luck with that, and I can assure you that you'll be different person once you finish reading that book.

The easiest thing to do is find a book that actually interests you. What I would do is ask my students what their favorite genre of movies. If they liked horror movies that’s the type of book I would recommend. If you aren’t reading something that catches your interest, you’re going to lose interest in reading altogether. Goodreads is a pretty cool app if you want to find new books to read. They send me emails with recommendations, and I can read about them and add them to my “want to read” list.

How do I lead myself to the joy of reading books?  Teach yourself memory training and speed reading. Do research on award-winning books, and anthologies. Don’t just jump into a massive tome and crush yourself. Some YA books are a great place to hover. Here’s where I have an unusual piece of advice. Look up authors who are compatible with your Sun Sign. This is your own sign, plus the other signs on an even number to yours. So, if your Capricorn, the signs to look at first are Pisces and Scorpio. (I’m no astrologer, but it works for me.)

Find what is in the book interesting. I hate reading, but sometimes the desire to learn overcomes my hatred of reading. Why do I hate to read? Because it is draining, and it is slow. I have ADHD and a naturally quick mind. I prefer watching video lectures of the subject that interests me. And even then I watch them at 2x the speed. In essence, reading by itself might not be something you like, but if you are interested in what is in the book, you might have the desire to read it.

To get to the point where you enjoy reading books you just have to find a book that you find interesting or like it’s subject, the book is going to do all the work from that point. The book will suck you in it’s world which the author has carefully constructed for the reader. Books are like video games, there is something for everyone and everyone can enjoy their magic.

Keep yourself busy in something else. As it has already been said, its a phase which you will get through. Go to a library or a book store and just browse. Look for titles that sound interesting. It may happen so that you might just pick up a title and start reading. Cheers.

Figure out what you really find interesting, do you like stories? Or do things need to be factual? Bestseller means zip by the way, they are almost always dreadful. Often individuals do not enjoy reading because they have a hard time understanding what they read. Start with a topic you enjoy. Get a audio book and read the print or electronic version at the same time as you listen to the book. Then slowly wean away from the audio version, asking yourself if you understood the content. Once your reading speed picks up, you will have an easier time staying interested. Wean off of the audio book when you feel “hooked” enough by the story to keep reading.

Start reading lite novels and anything that interests you no matter is it famous or not, if you found it interesting then give it a shot. I heartily endorse Eleanor Lang’s answer. But with one caveat. I support her bias toward independent bookstores and appreciate her comment about a more knowledgeable staff. But for someone struggling to know what they like to read; the public library might be a better choice simply because of the cost involved. Very little makes me unhappier than spending money on something (not just books) that I discover I don’t like. Checking out a mistake from the library is free. And librarians, in this mid-sized MN city anyway, are generally well read and happy to talk about books and make suggestions. Then advance to used books; which are cheap if not free. And as you become more confident about what you like and develop favorite authors and subjects, then advance to new books. At independent book stores. Some times new and used can be found in the same store.
Send me a message if you have not found a way to learn. I am a reading teacher who taught adults who did not learn to read. I have some ideas, if that is your situation.

Reading a book is a purely a means to an end. There is no glory to having read a book or reading twenty a day (unless you're the sort of person who revels in bragging about how many books you read in). You have to derive some benefit from it, enjoyment or  information or both. A mathematician reads maths book for enjoyment, a maths student reads the same books for the information it contains. Find something that interests you and find a book about that interest, the rest comes naturally.

Pick the genre that interests you most in other media. You like being spooked my fictional horrors on the big screen? Pick a horror book. Stephen King awaits you. You like epic space operas and futuristic sci-fi? Plenty of sci-fi books out there. Pick something by Frank Herbert, Philip K Dick or Harlan Ellison. You like medieval fantasy epics like Game of Thrones? This one’s easy. Just pick the actual books and start reading. No matter what genre you are interested in, there are countless interesting books waiting to be discovered. The first few books you read, you read because of your interest in that specific genre. Slowly you would start reading everything under the sun just for the love of reading.

If you are into ebooks (or not), check out Book Bub (www.bookbub.com), Robin Reads (www.robinreads.com), The Fussy Librarian (www.thefussylibrarian.com) and Freebooksy (www.freebooksy.com). These sites offer free to low cost ebooks. I have found many book series I enjoy simply by getting that first free book. Using a Nook or Kindle (or their apps), you get to explore many genres of books and writers. If you prefer paperbacks, at least these sites will allow you to check out (and in some cases preview) books to purchase or borrow from the local library. Of course some libraries now offer ebooks.

If you are looking to develop an interest in reading, starting with non-fiction may not be the best move - unless you pick books from a topic of very high interest to you that will hold your attention. I would suggest starting with fiction - first-rate, easy-to-read, un-put-down-able, short (but none-too-short) fiction. For me, when I want to relax, I go back to PG Wodehouse or Douglas Adams. They are both fun to read, class-A comedy works that can be taken up, read for a short while, and works that will bring you back to them, increasing your reading time naturally. When you participate actively in class you are also preparing for the exam, and also gain valuable tips for project work and other assignments. It is good to ask a lot of questions and also to question things in a constructive manner. If you are absent for some reason, remember to ask your classmates what was done and discussed. Ask them to clarify what remains unclear – this helps them to learn at the same time. Attending class has its benefits. It’s normal that things don't always go well during your studies. If you fail an exam, you just have to live and learn: what will I do better next time around? Avoiding difficult subjects is bad strategy. Be especially active in courses that seem difficult or unclear. Be bold and ask questions. Most likely you’ll be doing a favour also to other students, as it is probable that you are not the only one who doesn't understand. “If I don’t know something and ask, I remain ignorant for only a moment. If I don’t ask, I will remain ignorant also in the future.” Sometimes you might lose your study motivation. That’s quite normal too – and then it is good to go at it one step at a time. Once those course completions start piling up, it will once again be easier to get motivated for the final push. And always remember that employers like to hire graduates, not someone who has dropped out.
